content:
Khizer Asad is a recent graduate looking for a professional or research position. He is keen on pursuing a career in the public sector or with an NGO, and also actively seeking admission in to a graduate program. His research interests include the intersection between public policy and data science so to pursue evidence based policies.
Current work includes research on political and social sentiments in Pakistan using data from Twitter’s API. In addition to this, he is working on independent programming and statistics projects (read more in blog section). Khizer is very passionate about E-Sports, and in his extra time freelances as a commentator for Overwatch and VALORANT tournaments.
  Download my resumé.
summary: Khizer Asad is a recent graduate looking for a professional or research position. He is keen on pursuing a career in the public sector or with an NGO, and also actively seeking admission in to a graduate program.
title: Khizer Asad

content:
吳恩達 is a professor of artificial intelligence at the Stanford AI Lab. His research interests include distributed robotics, mobile computing and programmable matter. He leads the Robotic Neurobiology group, which develops self-reconfiguring robots, systems of self-organizing robots, and mobile sensor networks.
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Sed neque elit, tristique placerat feugiat ac, facilisis vitae arcu. Proin eget egestas augue. Praesent ut sem nec arcu pellentesque aliquet. Duis dapibus diam vel metus tempus vulputate.
summary: 吳恩達 is a professor of artificial intelligence at the Stanford AI Lab. His research interests include distributed robotics, mobile computing and programmable matter. He leads the Robotic Neurobiology group, which develops self-reconfiguring robots, systems of self-organizing robots, and mobile sensor networks.
title: 吳恩達

content:
Flexibility This feature can be used for publishing content such as:
 Online courses Project or software documentation Tutorials  The courses folder may be renamed. For example, we can rename it to docs for software/project documentation or tutorials for creating an online course.
Delete tutorials To remove these pages, delete the courses folder and see below to delete the associated menu link.
Update site menu After renaming or deleting the courses folder, you may wish to update any [[main]] menu links to it by editing your menu configuration at config/_default/menus.toml.
For example, if you delete this folder, you can remove the following from your menu configuration:
[[main]] name = "Courses" url = "courses/" weight = 50  Or, if you are creating a software documentation site, you can rename the courses folder to docs and update the associated Courses menu configuration to:
[[main]] name = "Docs" url = "docs/" weight = 50  Update the docs menu If you use the docs layout, note that the name of the menu in the front matter should be in the form [menu.X] where X is the folder name. Hence, if you rename the courses/example/ folder, you should also rename the menu definitions in the front matter of files within courses/example/ from [menu.example] to [menu.<NewFolderName>].
summary: Learn how to use Academic's docs layout for publishing online courses, software documentation, and tutorials.
title: Overview

title: Example Page 2

content:
Click on the Slides button above to view the built-in slides feature.   Slides can be added in a few ways:
 Create slides using Academic’s Slides feature and link using slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes.  Further talk details can easily be added to this page using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.
summary: An example talk using Academic's Markdown slides feature.
title: Example Talk

content:
IntroductionI was recently tasked with extracting a list of products sold on hotel supply websites. A recurring pattern I noticed in these various sites was they were mostly made using website building services, the most prevalent being Squarespace. This streamlined my job as it meant that the construction of the varying sites would be very similar, so if I wanted to write a web scraping tool in Python to extract all the products they sell I could use the same code with minimal changes. For this example I’ll be using the website https://www.truenorthdistributors.com/ .
TL;DR you can find the code on my github here
The CodeThe starting point of course was first getting the links for all products. There are already many examples of this online so I just used this guide, and wrote all the links to a csv file. Now you’ll have a list of ALL webpages of your desired website, which will likely include non-product links as well. Narrowing this down to just product pages is pretty simple, just find a common phrase in only the product links and filter by that. In the case of True North they have a common link for all products depending on the category it’s in (e.g. /hotel-supplies/ or /hospitality-supplies).
Now we have a csv file with the links to all products we can get going. Using the help of another guide I produced the code you’ll find below:
import requestsfrom bs4 import BeautifulSoupimport pandasimport sysfile = pandas.read_csv('[Insert links csv file path]')link_list = file['Link'].tolist()master_l = []master_p = []master_d = []for index, links in enumerate(link_list):product_list = []description_list = []URL = linkspage = requests.get(URL)soup = BeautifulSoup(page.content, 'html.parser')results = soup.find(id='content')if results is None:continuejob_elems = results.find_all('div', class_='sqs-block html-block sqs-block-html')for num, job_elem in enumerate(job_elems):list = []title = job_elem.find('h2')description = job_elem.find_all('p', class_='')if title is None:continueproduct_list.insert(num, title.get_text())for i, x in enumerate(description):if description[i] is None:continuelist.insert(i, description[i].text)des_output = ', '.join(list)description_list.insert(num, des_output)master_p.extend(product_list)master_d.extend(description_list)for count in range(len(product_list)):master_l.append(links)dictionary = {'Link': master_l, 'Product': master_p, 'Description': master_d}df = pandas.DataFrame(dictionary)df.to_csv('[Insert csv file path]')This will leave you with a csv file containing all product names, descriptions, and its respective link. Depending on the website you run this on, you will need to inspect the HTML of one of the product webpages and change the Beautiful Soup functions filters to make sure you catch the information you need.
summary: IntroductionI was recently tasked with extracting a list of products sold on hotel supply websites. A recurring pattern I noticed in these various sites was they were mostly made using website building services, the most prevalent being Squarespace.
title: Squarespace Sales Site Scraping Tool (Python)

content:
Executive summaryPetit Poll has been asked to produce a monthly survey for the National Democratic Party (NDP), to provide them with data that can assist in their campaign for the 2022 Ontario general assembly elections. We have designed a mailed survey targeting voters in all 124 electoral districts with 28,000 surveys sent out monthly, which should yield approximately 7,000 responses per month with am expense budget totaling $5,000/month. The goal of this survey is to provide the NDP with very actionable data that includes respondents: demographics, political history, and political views. The questions are designed so the help with the party’s macro policy for the province, and also for their individual candidates to make use of in their own electoral districts. Using the data as feedback over time the NDP can optimize their campaigning strategies to win a majority in the 2022 general election.
IntroductionIn the 2018 Ontario general election for the province’s legislative assembly the Liberal party lost their majority rule of the assembly after winning the last 4 elections. Ontario is a historically Liberal province, though due to a provincial campaign marred with controversies in 2018 they lost their majority to the Progressive Conservatives (PC) party. The New Democratic Party (NDP) also greatly benefited in 2018 by more than doubling their previous number of seats in the assembly and becoming the official opposition party (CBC 2018).
Looking forward to the 2022 Ontario general election the NDP may have a legitimate chance of taking the election given the PC party’s low approval rating during their term (Fournier 2019). To improve their chances of winning in 2022 the NDP has hired Petit Poll to conduct surveying of Ontario citizens to improve their campaigning.
Petit Poll has designed a monthly survey targeting individuals in all 124 of Ontario’s electoral districts that will gauge political views and leanings by demographics. The NDP can then employ these results to optimize their campaigning strategies leading in to 2022.
Survey methodologyThe population frame is all eligible voters living in Ontario, while the sampling frame is those we can reach via a mail interview. In order to provide the most valuable survey data for the NDP’s use a stratified randomly sampled with replacement methodology. The goal is to target people in every electoral district so to have data valuable for the party’s macro provincial campaign as well as for every NDP party candidate in each electoral district.
For this study the most robust medium of surveying would be mail in surveys. It will allow us to target Ontario residents specifically and will have a reasonably high response rate (Deane et al. 2019).
With a monthly budget of approximately $5,000 ($60,000/year) we have designed a survey methodology to target about 28,125 people monthly. It is budgeted accordingly:
$500 incentives ($50 x 10 gift card raffle)$4500 Canada Post mailing costs ($0.16 per letter)To ensure the best sampling practices the 28,125 letters sent out using Canada Post’s business services will be divided up between electoral district by their population (e.g. if two districts have 100,000 and 30,000 residents the same percent of their residents will receive the survey). Canada Post’s services include mailing to randomized addresses in any area so random sampling is fairly easy.
We estimate that the response rate will be %25 (Deane et al. 2019), hence we will receive approximately 7,000 responses per month or 84,000 annually. Additionally the data collected will be anonymous respondents named and addresses will be collected though kept independent of their responses for the random gift card draw. For the convenience of the respondents they will have the option to either mail back their responses or visit a link of the email to complete the survey online. Only those of age to vote and are Canadian citizens will be eligible to complete the survey.
DiscussionThe survey that respondents receive consist of three parts: demographic information, political history, political views. The demographics section will allow the party to filter responses by certain population at their discretion so they can see the interests of different groups and know how to market to them accordingly. the second section, political history, will allow the party to see likelihood of the respondent voting in the next general election as well as their party affiliations. These can be informative of how and which non-voters the NDP can mobilize, and which groups of people to campaign for (e.g. to gain new voters the NDP will likely have to invest more in non-NDP supporters). The last section is perhaps the most critical for framing the campaigning efforts, as it shows us the opinions of respondents regarding issues on the NDP agenda. By seeing the issues voters are most or least passionate on it will allow the party to form the most optimal political campaigning. To see all 35 survey questions and the reasoning behind them please refer to the appendix of the report.
Now we will simulate some responses to see exactly how the data can be used on a monthly basis. Using census data for our demographics we randomly generate 7000 responses. So for instance we could see the level of education of our respondents, from historical polling data we know that this is a significant variable in influencing electoral tendencies (Statistics Canada).
Figure 1 shows us the level of education that respondents have attained, the two most prominent categories being a Bachelors degree or higher and a college or vocation diploma/certificate. Data such as this is openly available from the census and several other sources so this in itself is not the most valuable. However this is where the value of part 2 and 3 of the survey come in to play. For instance, now we are able to extract the likelihood of someone intending to vote in 2022 given their level of education.

6px;border-top-color: #D3D3D3;}#ynprzipmhx .gt_striped {background-color: rgba(128, 128, 128, 0.05);}#ynprzipmhx .gt_table_body {border-top-style: solid;border-top-width: 2px;border-top-color: #D3D3D3;border-bottom-style: solid;border-bottom-width: 2px;border-bottom-color: #D3D3D3;}#ynprzipmhx .gt_footnotes {color: #333333;background-color: #DFF1FF;border-bottom-style: none;border-bottom-width: 2px;border-bottom-color: #D3D3D3;border-left-style: none;border-left-width: 2px;border-left-color: #D3D3D3;border-right-style: none;border-right-width: 2px;border-right-color: #D3D3D3;}#ynprzipmhx .gt_footnote {margin: 0px;font-size: 90%;padding: 4px;}#ynprzipmhx .gt_sourcenotes {color: #333333;background-color: #DFF1FF;border-bottom-style: none;border-bottom-width: 2px;border-bottom-color: #D3D3D3;border-left-style: none;border-left-width: 2px;border-left-color: #D3D3D3;border-right-style: none;border-right-width: 2px;border-right-color: #D3D3D3;}#ynprzipmhx .gt_sourcenote {font-size: 90%;padding: 4px;}#ynprzipmhx .gt_left {text-align: left;}#ynprzipmhx .gt_center {text-align: center;}#ynprzipmhx .gt_right {text-align: right;font-variant-numeric: tabular-nums;}#ynprzipmhx .gt_font_normal {font-weight: normal;}#ynprzipmhx .gt_font_bold {font-weight: bold;}#ynprzipmhx .gt_font_italic {font-style: italic;}#ynprzipmhx .gt_super {font-size: 65%;}#ynprzipmhx .gt_footnote_marks {font-style: italic;font-size: 65%;}Figure 2Do you intend on voting in the 2020 general election?Education LevelNumber of Responses'Yes' to Voting in 2020RatioBachelors+225013160.58Diploma/certificate219512520.57High school diploma16819330.56No diploma7363980.54Some university169960.57From the fourth column in Figure 2 we can observe the ratio of people that say yes to intending on voting in the 2022 general election. Using a statistic like this the party can shape their campaigning strategies to different demographics. For instance in this simulated data those with a Bachelor’s degree or greater have a greater chance of voting than someone without any diploma. So for higher educated citizens the campaigning strategy may rely more on policy, whilst for the less educated the focus may be more so on mobilizing the non-voters.
Part 3 of the survey collects opinions on specific policies that are within the NDP’s agenda. Using data from these responses we can see which policies people of various backgrounds hold most valuable and can adjust campaigning accordingly to maximize potential voters.
Figure 3 serves as an example of such, it shows us the level of agreement respondents had to the proposition of divesting from police services. Of course in real, non-randomly simulated data the responses ought to be more diverse which would allow for a better gauge of the public’s opinion of the policy. Adding further nuance to this example, we could observe the responses by age group.
Figure 4 shows us what that data may look like. Information such as this can be a powerful tool for shaping the party’s actions and growing their voter base. If we are able to isolate which groups of people strongly favour certain policies, they can be marketed to accordingly. Additionally another benefit of this survey design is that the individual NDP candidates can use the data exclusively from their electoral district to see what their residents value the most. This can go a long way in getting voters to change their allegiances if they notice another party’s candidate is better catering to their demands.
As this is a monthly recurring survey (though not necessarily always sent to the same people), the party’s administration can use the data to also determine if their current endeavours are working in their favour or if they need to change up their campaigning.
CommentsThe data used in these examples was randomly simulated, and is not accurate nor statistically significant, so we can not demonstrate the use of summary statistics. However when real data is collected the party will be able to use various analytic methods to extract the strongest interactions between variables to optimize their platform.
Some caveats, firstly the final survey is 35 questions, which provides a good actionable amount of data, but of course there are some potential questions that had to be left out in order to ensure a higher response rate for peoples time sake. Additionally mailed surveys may contain a sampling bias, as those without permanent addresses will not be able to receive the survey. Furthermore, in family households there may be a recurring pattern of who in the household handles the mail, which may lead to an over representation of a certain party in the data. With these limitations in mind Petit Poll is still confident in this methodology, as it is the most effective method given the available resources.
SurveyLink to the survey
AppendixDiscussion on question selection
Part 1 (demographics): the goal was not to overload on questions to create dozens of categories, rather using the available literature to only include variables known to have a known correlation with voter behaviour (Statistics Canada).Includes questions on: age, gender, race/ethnicity, immigrant status, education.Also including a question on the number of people in their household, as families are more likely to vote for the same party, so we can gauge an approximate number of voters.Part 2 (political history): This section is to identify the political tendencies of respondents.The first few questions are designed to determine if the respondent will be voting in 2022, and where their party allegiances lie.Question 6 from the polling literature is an important question to include, as often the public’s perception of who will win can shape their behaviour and also be a good estimator of election outcomes (Deane et al. 2019).
Question 7 will help measure the political engagement of respondents in order to determine what depth of campaigning to use.Part 3 (political opinions): We collect the views of the public on policies in the NDP charter. Polarizing policy statements are made so to illicit a strong reaction from respondents to the questions in the form of agreement or disagreement. This data can be much more valuable to the party as opposed to general less polarizing statements that may not provide as actionable data (e.g. we should decrease taxes, or we should spend more on education).Link to code used
References“Census Profile 2016.” Statistics Canada, 2017, www12.statcan.gc.ca/census-recensement/2016/dp-pd/prof/index.cfm?Lang=E.
Deane, Claudia, et al. “Election 2020 Polling Field Guide.” Pew Research Center Methods, Pew Research Center, 30 Dec. 2019, www.pewresearch.org/methods/2019/11/19/a-field-guide-to-polling-election-2020-edition/.
Fournier, Philippee J. “338Canada: How Bad Things Are for Doug Ford.” Macleans.ca, 18 Dec. 2019, www.macleans.ca/politics/338canada-how-bad-things-are-for-doug-ford/.
“Graphics & Charts.” Elections Ontario, 2018, results.elections.on.ca/en/graphics-charts.
Jeffrey B. Arnold (2019). ggthemes: Extra Themes, Scales and Geoms for ‘ggplot2’. R packageversion 4.2.0. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=ggthemes
JJ Allaire and Yihui Xie and Jonathan McPherson and Javier Luraschi and Kevin Ushey and AronAtkins and Hadley Wickham and Joe Cheng and Winston Chang and Richard Iannone (2020).rmarkdown: Dynamic Documents for R. R package version 2.3. URL https://rmarkdown.rstudio.com.
“Ontario Election Results From CBC News.” CBCnews, CBC/Radio Canada, 7 June 2018, newsinteractives.cbc.ca/onvotes/results/.
Statistics Canada. “Factors Associated with Voting.” Statistics Canada: Canada’s National Statistical Agency , 27 Nov. 2015, www150.statcan.gc.ca/n1/pub/75-001-x/2012001/article/11629-eng.htm.
Richard Iannone, Joe Cheng and Barret Schloerke (2020). gt: Easily CreatePresentation-Ready Display Tables. R package version 0.2.2.https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=gt
R Core Team (2020). R: A language and environment for statisticalcomputing. R Foundation for Statistical Computing, Vienna, Austria.URL https://www.R-project.org/.
R Core Team (2020). R: A language and environment for statistical computing. R Foundation forStatistical Computing, Vienna, Austria. URL https://www.R-project.org/.
Wickham et al., (2019). Welcome to the tidyverse. Journal of OpenSource Software, 4(43), 1686, https://doi.org/10.21105/joss.01686
summary: Executive summaryPetit Poll has been asked to produce a monthly survey for the National Democratic Party (NDP), to provide them with data that can assist in their campaign for the 2022 Ontario general assembly elections.
title: Petit Poll: Survey Proposal for the National Democratic Party

content:
AbstractThis study seeks to examine the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic on the occupancy of Toronto’s homeless shelters. From the public Shelter Occupancy data set it is observed that during the spread of the virus, demand for spaces in shelters decreased significantly. Although there is not enough data available to fully comprehend the causal factors of this perhaps surprising result.
IntroductionThe Toronto open data portal contains many up to date public data sets concerning the cities on goings, one of which is the homeless shelter occupancy statistics. It is conveniently for our use updated every day so we can examine the daily changes of those utilizing the city’s public shelters (City of Toronto 2020). Given the availability of this data alongside the obvious confirmed COVID-19 cases data for the city I decided to examine the impact of the pandemic on Toronto’s shelters (City of Toronto 2020). The results that were observed are quite interesting, and perhaps counter-intuitive.
To run a comparative analysis of these two data sets the following variables were used:
Shelter data set: date, daily capacity, daily occupancy
COVID-19 data set: date, daily new cases
Data ExplorationTo first contextualize the analysis, the timeline of positive COVID-19 cases in Toronto can be seen in Figure 1. The extent of the virus was realized in mid-March when new cases had started to significantly escalate. At this point the city of Toronto and provincial government began to implement restrictions on the number of people allowed in enclosed areas, including in public spaces such as homeless shelters (Nielsen 2020). These were put in place for the safety of citizens health and to mitigate the spread of the virus, though for spaces such as shelters this could have potentially worked in the detriment of those that rely on the shelter system. Perhaps even more so during a period of economic downturn that saw unemployment in the city rise by almost 10%, which could potentially cause a rise in demand for shelters with the looming housing crisis (Statistics Canada 2020).
As crowd restrictions had to be put in place, the number of people that existing homeless shelters could accommodate would have to decrease. The evident effect of the pandemic on shelter capacity is reflected below.
Figure 2 shows that prior to COVID-19 protocols shelters had the capacity to accommodate between 7000-7500 people daily. And we can see in that in response to the pandemic the city actually increased their capacity in March by re-purposing commercial spaces such as hotels and motels that were closed as part of the COVID-19 response (City of Toronto 2020). However we surprisingly see a sharp decline in capacity after then till now (September). The data set’s description states that capacity is not a metric defined by the number of available beds, rather it is actually based on the funding provided to the city’s shelters. Hence we can see that funding for shelters’ capacity actually decreased during the pandemic. Now this posits the question of whether this was a supply or demand side shock, mechanistically what caused this decline in shelters capacity?
The data presented below may help us answer that question:
Figure 3 provides us with the insight we may need to answer the posited question. The top diagram visualizes the occupancy of Toronto’s shelters, and was affected similar to how shelter capacities were affected by the virus. From April when COVID-19 cases in the city began to significantly rise shelters started to actually decrease in occupancy. For those suffering from a lack of housing one may think that demand for shelters would increase during the pandemic, as people would be averse to spending the night in public or crowded areas.
Though we can see this was actually not the case, not only did the number of occupants change, Figure 3 highlights how the percentage of occupancy decreased as well (i.e. number of occupants/capacity). Prior to COVID-19 protocols we can see that shelters were sitting at around 95% of capacity, however from April onwards the figure actually began to decline, falling as low as 65%. Hence it is evident that the decrease in funding for capacity in shelters was actually caused by a decrease in demand from the public.
Closing RemarksOf course the available statistics can’t explain the whole story, so it would be unwise to simply conclude that demand for shelters decreased, hence the city began to invest less in them. The data set lacks some critical information that would assist in explaining the mechanism by which this has occured. One of the reasons being a temporary housing program put in to place during the pandemic, which re-settled some shelter users in to apartments to further curb the spread of the virus (Kivanc 2020). The figures from this program were unfortunately not included in the shelters data set.
Additionally many members of the homeless community became concerned with the response of some shelters to the pandemic, citing that many were not taking social distancing protocols seriously. This coupled with news of the virus spreading in some shelters pressured many to decide to stop spending nights at the shelter they would usually frequent, and rather look for alternatives including homeless encampments where they would have the safety of having their own tents (Medford 2020, Ferreira 2020).
Whether the city’s COVID-19 response with respect to the homeless community has been successful is yet to be seen, more research in to shelter users reaction to the pandemic would need to be conducted. All figures have been compiled together below for the convenience of the reader:
All code can be found here
ReferencesCity of Toronto. (2020). COVID-19 Cases in Toronto. Retrieved from https://open.toronto.ca/dataset/covid-19-cases-in-toronto/.
City of Toronto. (2020). Daily Shelter Occupancy. Retrieved from https://open.toronto.ca/dataset/daily-shelter-occupancy/.
City of Toronto. (2020, August 07). City of Toronto COVID-19 Response for People Experiencing Homelessness. Retrieved from https://www.toronto.ca/news/city-of-toronto-covid-19-response-for-people-experiencing-homelessness/
Ferreira, J. (2020, May 23). The toll COVID-19 is taking on Canada’s homeless. Retrieved from https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/the-toll-covid-19-is-taking-on-canada-s-homeless-1.4950722
Jeffrey B. Arnold (2019). ggthemes: Extra Themes, Scales and Geoms for ‘ggplot2’. R packageversion 4.2.0. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=ggthemes
JJ Allaire and Yihui Xie and Jonathan McPherson and Javier Luraschi and Kevin Ushey and AronAtkins and Hadley Wickham and Joe Cheng and Winston Chang and Richard Iannone (2020).rmarkdown: Dynamic Documents for R. R package version 2.3. URL https://rmarkdown.rstudio.com.
Kivanc, J. (2020, August 04). ‘COVID made my life better,’ Toronto’s homeless say of temporary apartments. Retrieved from https://www.cp24.com/news/covid-made-my-life-better-toronto-s-homeless-say-of-temporary-apartments-1.5050104
Medford, M. (2020, August 01). Refugee Shares Story Of Living Through Pandemic In Homeless Shelter. Retrieved from https://www.huffingtonpost.ca/entry/toronto-homeless-shelter-pandemic-covid_ca_5f035e1cc5b6ca97092211f9
Nielsen, K. (2020, July 16). A timeline of the novel coronavirus in Ontario. Retrieved from https://globalnews.ca/news/6859636/ontario-coronavirus-timeline/
R Core Team (2020). R: A language and environment for statistical computing. R Foundation forStatistical Computing, Vienna, Austria. URL https://www.R-project.org/.
Statistics Canada. (2020). Labour force characteristics by census metropolitan area. Retrieved from https://www150.statcan.gc.ca/t1/tbl1/en/tv.action?pid=1410029401
Wickham et al., (2019). Welcome to the tidyverse. Journal of Open Source Software, 4(43),1686, https://doi.org/10.21105/joss.01686
summary: AbstractThis study seeks to examine the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic on the occupancy of Toronto’s homeless shelters. From the public Shelter Occupancy data set it is observed that during the spread of the virus, demand for spaces in shelters decreased significantly.
title: Toronto's Shelters During the COVID-19 Pandemic

content:
Create slides in Markdown with Academic Academic | Documentation
 Features  Efficiently write slides in Markdown 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides Supports speaker notes Mobile friendly slides   Controls  Next: Right Arrow or Space Previous: Left Arrow Start: Home Finish: End Overview: Esc Speaker notes: S Fullscreen: F Zoom: Alt + Click PDF Export: E   Code Highlighting Inline code: variable
Code block:
porridge = "blueberry" if porridge == "blueberry": print("Eating...")   Math In-line math: $x + y = z$
Block math:
$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$
 Fragments Make content appear incrementally
{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}  Press Space to play!
One  Two  Three 
 A fragment can accept two optional parameters:
 class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS) weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears   Speaker Notes Add speaker notes to your presentation
{{% speaker_note %}} - Only the speaker can read these notes - Press `S` key to view {{% /speaker_note %}}  Press the S key to view the speaker notes!
 Only the speaker can read these notes Press S key to view    Themes  black: Black background, white text, blue links (default) white: White background, black text, blue links league: Gray background, white text, blue links beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links    night: Black background, thick white text, orange links serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links simple: White background, black text, blue links solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links   Custom Slide Customize the slide style and background
{{< slide background-image="/media/boards.jpg" >}} {{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}} {{< slide class="my-style" >}}   Custom CSS Example Let’s make headers navy colored.
Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:
.reveal section h1, .reveal section h2, .reveal section h3 { color: navy; }   Questions? Ask
Documentation
summary: An introduction to using Academic's Slides feature.
title: Slides

summary: An example of linking directly to an external project website using `external_link`.
title: External Project
